Yes, some Spanish filmmakers during Franco's regime did make films that were critical of his regime, although it was very difficult to do so openly. 

Under Franco's regime, censorship was pervasive, and films that dared to be critical of the government were often banned or heavily edited. Despite this, some Spanish filmmakers managed to create subtly critical films that used allegory or metaphor to express their discontent with the regime. 

For example, the film "El verdugo" (The Executioner) was released in 1963 by the Spanish director Luis García Berlanga. While the film was disguised as a comedy, it was a scathing critique of Franco's regime and its lack of individual rights. The film faced severe censorship and was forbidden to be shown until several years later. 

Other notable Spanish artists, such as the writer Camilo Jose Cela, regularly showed dissent towards the Francoist regime. However, these individuals faced significant repression from the regime, and in some cases, found their work censored or banned entirely. Despite the obstacles, some Spanish filmmakers during Franco's time were able to convey their criticisms of the regime in creative ways.
